what's your original problem?
if you want to do lots of customization, or different power user things, there's no way around CLI.  It's less true in Windows than Linux, but even in Windows it's true.
luckily, CLI is really powerful.  Unluckily, it's ridiculously hard to learn.  That's the whole point of a GUI, and we wouldn't have a computer in every home (in many countries) without a GUI.
I just saw something earlier today about a tutorial for burning ISO files.  I can't remember where - might have been a video tutorial.  have you searched on ubuntu's site?
you're trying to burn an 800 MB image? how big is your disk?  CD-Rs are usually only 700 MB I thought.

You want to get better at CLI?  I'd just take one task at a time, and figure out how to do it.  Find a tutorial or how-to and go from there.
what I've done is learned a basic set of commands, and worked from those on specific tasks.
if you want, pm me and I'll share what I think are the "getting started" commands.  :)
yeah, I feel your pain.
I think there's an online version of man, but really your best bet is to look for specific help on a given command.
for example, I wanted to know what the different colors mean when you do an "ls" command (like dir, for directory).
good luck.  I don't have time to search right now, but I'm sure the answer is out there.
